image.altText: Fire trucks near Nuyina berth, Hobart

props.synopsis: An area of Hobart's waterfront was cordoned off on Sunday because of a jet fuel spill, with fire crews seen near Australia's Antarctic icebreaker Nuyina.

title.children: Jet fuel spill shuts part of Hobart's waterfront, with people told to close windows due to hazardous materials

image.altText: Female Tasmania Police officer with breathalyser at random testing station

props.synopsis: After being arrested the first time, the Deloraine woman was disqualified from driving for two years, but that allegedly did not stop her getting back behind the wheel again the following day.

title.children: Tasmanian woman caught driving five times over legal limit â€” twice in 12 hours

image.altText: A man wearing a beanie and wet-weather gear, seen from above, holds onto a rope while partially submerged in water.

props.synopsis: Authorities say a 65-year-old Lithuanian man who had his left leg amputated at the knee during a complex rescue operation in Tasmania's remote south-west is now in a stable condition in hospital.

title.children: Man who had leg amputated in Franklin River rescue now in a stable condition

image.altText: Riders on a trail at Maydena mountain bike park, Tasmania.

props.synopsis: A mountain bike rider is airlifted to hospital after a crash at Maydena, north-west of Hobart, which is home to world-famous biking trails.

title.children: Mountain bike rider suffers 'serious injuries' in crash at Maydena

image.altText: A woman sitting against a kitchen counter at home.

props.synopsis: Mum of two Jane Dutton has made the call to shut down her kids' social media before the ban comes into effect from the end of next year. Like many parents, she felt pressure to allow her children onto the platforms in the first place.

title.children: Mum who let kids onto social media so they would 'fit in' starts under-16s ban straight away

image.altText: 19-year-old girl witih hair in braids and white top looks out to distance

props.synopsis: The major parties are united on the need to protect young people by banning them from social media. But experts say dialling back something that has become so pervasive in the lives of children and teenagers requires nuance â€” and more time â€” to get right.

title.children: Anjali was 13 when she found her community online. She worries for those who now won't have the chance

image.altText: Caitlin Foord applauds the referee as she shows Kaka a yellow card

props.synopsis: The Matildas are back for another crack at Brazil, hoping to avenge their Brisbane defeat when they meet again on the Gold Coast. Follow the action in our live blog.

title.children: Matildas star injured in warm up ahead of Brazil clash on the Gold Coast

image.altText: Jiyai Shin smiles as people pour water on her head in celebration

props.synopsis: South Korea's Riyai Shin holds through a nervy final stretch to win her second Australian Open, while unheralded American Ryggs Johnston shocks the field to lift the Stonehaven Cup.

title.children: Shin holds on for Australian Open triumph as unheralded American breaks Aussie hearts

image.altText: A soldier waves from an army-khaki vehicle on a road surrounded by damaged houses and short shrubs

props.synopsis: A shock four-day offensive in Syria's north-east has seen territory held by the Assad regime since 2016 retaken by militant groups aiming to overthrow the government.Â

title.children: 'Game-changing' advances in Syria's civil war as government withdraws

image.altText: A rescue crewman looking out of a helicopter over a mountain.

props.synopsis: Two tourists who became lost while hiking at Cape Hillsborough National Park in north Queensland have been found during a large-scale search.Â

title.children: Tourists who became lost on bushwalk found by helicopter in major search operation

image.altText: Rows of houses and streets line a village with mountains in the background.

props.synopsis: Americans unhappy with the US election result are being encouraged to move to Italy. But will anyone take up the offer?

title.children: A home on an Italian island can be bought for only 1 euro â€” but there are some catches

image.altText: Snake catcher Tim Nanninga captures a tiger snake on the Monash Freeway.

props.synopsis: You might have heard of the movie Snakes on a Plane. But what happens if you're driving down a busy city freeway, and you suddenly, terrifyingly, feel a tiger snake slithering up your leg?

title.children: Rattled driver forced to pull over on busy Melbourne freeway after tiger snake slithers up leg

image.altText: A hand holds a smooth chocolate  bar

props.synopsis: A 34-year-old British man has thought his unwrinkled chocolate bar was a new cost-cutting measure. After sharing the find, he's been handed Â£2 in compensation.

title.children: Smooth chocolate bar wins British man Â£2 in compensation after viral post

image.altText: Selina Middleton EDITED

props.synopsis: Methylamphetamine is taking a toll on the central Kimberley town of Fitzroy Crossing. It is a story playing out across Australia's top end.

title.children: Cheaper than grog and marijuana, meth is wreaking havoc on this small town

image.altText: Man in a judge's wig and uniform with a purple sash, looking into a mirror.

props.synopsis: From musical outcast to Judge to cult punk rock favourite. Judge Simon Stretton has bucked several trends across duelling careers.

title.children: Once 'hated, ignored and rejected', this little-known punk rock band led by a former judge has found a cult following

image.altText: A graphic artwork of a man in a suit with his eyes obscured, with cameras and a large building also visible in the background

props.synopsis: Being a secret agent might seem like a glamorous job, but agencies in the West are struggling to attract the next generation of spies due to many young people prioritising issues such as climate change and COVID-19 over national security.

title.children: Britain and Australia have a spy shortage and recruiting the next generation is proving difficult

image.altText: Loyal Wingman plane in flight

props.synopsis: The Future Fund currently holds more than half a billion dollars worth of shares in weapons manufacturers and war-related companies, but is it time we all started talking about its larger legacy, and the nature of its "wealth" we plan to hand to future Australians?

title.children: Australia's Future Fund invests in the global arms industry. Are the returns worth it?

image.altText: A photo of a white car with blasted windows and doors.

props.synopsis: The food charity says it is pausing its operations in Gaza after a vehicle carrying its staff members was hit by an Israeli air strike.

title.children: Israeli military says it was targeting Hamas 'terrorist' in strike that reportedly killed three World Central Kitchen aid workers

image.altText: An ice climber carefully strikes the wall of ice with his ice axe.

props.synopsis: Ice climbing, introduced to Australia by migrants in the 1960s, is booming as extreme sport lovers seek higher thrills â€” but with such a short season, you have to book early.

title.children: 'You wouldn't believe it's Australia': Climbing walls of ice in our own backyard

image.altText: Blue tarp can be seen at the side of the factory outside Vientiane, Laos

props.synopsis: A Laos government document obtained by the ABC suggests the source of a methanol poisoning outbreak that killed six tourists is a rundown factory outside of Vientiane that was making vodka and whisky.

title.children: Laos government document points to rundown factory as source of methanol poisoning

image.altText: An image of Canada Water's bright red boardwalk along the water, with the development in the background.

props.synopsis: Australia's biggest super fund has invested millions of dollars into a London development, which will deliver homes, workspaces and a retail precinct in London at the same time Australia's housing crisis is in full swing.

title.children: A new town centre in London promises to build 3,000 homes. It's being partly funded by everyday Australians' super

image.altText: A man looks at a pin-sized object in his hand in front of a metal machine

props.synopsis: For almost 20 years, the Bali Nine have lived day by day behind bars in Indonesia. Now, the one day they have dreamed of more than anything else may be close.

title.children: Bali Nine dare to dream of coming home as Indonesian president mulls transfer to Australia

image.altText: Melbourne Renegades players celebrate in a group as Laura Harris walks off

props.synopsis: West Indies star Hayley Matthews fires with bat and ball against Brisbane Heat at the MCG, powering the Melbourne Renegades to their maiden WBBL title.

title.children: Matthews leads Renegades to WBBL title in rain-affected MCG final against Heat

image.altText: A group of young men and women in island shirts and island dresses.

props.synopsis: A landmark case that began in a Pacific classroom and could change the course of future climate talks is about to be heard in the International Court of Justice.

title.children: The 'David and Goliath moment' at The Hague that could change future climate talks

image.altText: A woman in a yellow top and teens clutches her stomach on a couch

props.synopsis: Visanne, also known by the generic name dienogest, will have its cost reduced from more than $800 per year for a course of daily tablets to $380 per year, or around $90 per year for pension and concession card holders.

title.children: Endometriosis treatment to be listed on PBS for the first time in 30 years

image.altText: A satellite image of lava snaking through mountainous terrain

props.synopsis: Iceland's famous Blue Lagoon has been temporarily closed as lava continues to spill from a volcanic fissure on the Reykjanes Peninsula.

title.children: Icelandic volcano eruption forces closure of tourist destination as wall of lava cuts off roads

image.altText: An older man wearing a hat and blue shirt holding a white dog standing next to two Australian kelpies

props.synopsis: From babies and puppies, to charity work and training, this is what the participants of ABC iview's Muster Dogs series are up to now.

title.children: Frank Finger, Zoe Miller and other Muster Dogs stars on life after the series

image.altText: Michael Callaghan and Gregor Cullen at Redback studios in black and white.

props.synopsis: In the 80s, hipster youths Michael Callaghan and Gregor Cullen screen-printed street posters in a park in Wollongong. Their posters are now sitting in collections in major art institutions.Â

title.children: How screen-printed 1980s posters from Wollongong came to sit in major art collections

image.altText: Australian actor Hugo Weaving with a white beard smiling with a santa het.

props.synopsis: How do you turn an iconic Aussie song into a movie? In the case of How To Make Gravy, the secret is in the source... material.Â

title.children: A Christmas movie musical set in prison? Paul Kelly's How To Make Gravy gets the film treatment

image.altText: A young white boy with red hair sitting in a wheelchair smiling at an adult. They're in a school classroom

props.synopsis: Starting school can be challenging for any child, but there can be extra difficulties for those with disability. ABC NEWS looks at two examples of public schools and families working together to set students with disability up for success.

title.children: When looking at schools for her son, Fiona interviewed the staff â€“ not the other way around

image.altText: Gavin Smith stands at the office in the caravan park wearing a green shirt and hat smiling.

props.synopsis:
It's not your typical retirement plan but Gavin Smith is in it "boots and all" giving new life to a caravan park in a town he first fell in love with 50 years ago.Â 

Â Â

title.children: For Gavin's 70th birthday, he bought himself a caravan park in the outback

image.altText: The side of a police car with the logo and word Police.

props.synopsis: Police said the boy, who was a passenger in the vehicle, was trapped in the car after the crash. Three other boys have been arrested.

title.children: Teenage boy fighting for life after stolen car crashes into tree

image.altText: crowds with hands in the air in front of the stage at Meredith

props.synopsis: In a year when many Australian music festivals have announced they're folding or postponed, Meredith Music Festival will nurture its familiar rituals like the brass band once again.

title.children: Regulars at music festival that's been running for 32 years think they know the secret to its success
